sen.j: 公主（こうしゅ）とは、中国で皇帝の娘を指す。
sen.e: Koshu (公主) indicates a daughter of the Emperor in China.
Koshu (公主) indicates the daughters of the Chinese Emperors.
sen.cmt: 特定の皇帝の娘のように読めないよう表現を改めました。
sen.e: Koshu (公主) indicates the daughters of the Chinese Emperors.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: またはその人の称号のこと。
sen.e: Or it indicates the title of the daughter.
This was also used a title for them.
sen.cmt: 表現の変更をしました。
sen.e: This was also used a title for them.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 古くは化粧領として拝領した土地の地名を取って「○○公主」と呼んだ（例太平公主、安楽公主）が、明・清の時代の称号は多く雅称で、これに嵌めることはできない。
sen.e: In the ancient times, the daughters were called like '- Koshu' by toponym of the land conferred on them as they married, for example, Taihei Koshu and Anraku Koshu; but during the Ming and Qing periods, the title Koshu were mostly elegant names instead of toponym.

In ancient times, those daughters were called with the names of the lands conferred on them as they married, in a form of the place name and 'Koshu" (e.g. Taihei Koshu, Anraku Koshu), but this cannot be applied to the names in the Ming and Qing periods because the title became treated as a title indicating nobility.
sen.cmt: toponym で呼ばれているというより、土地の名前を付けて呼ばれていたと平たい表現の原文なのでそのようにしました。
sen.e: In ancient times, those daughters were called with the names of the lands conferred on them as they married, in a form of the place name and 'Koshu' (e.g. Taihei Koshu, Anraku Koshu), but this cannot be applied to the names in the Ming and Qing periods because the title became treated as a title indicating nobility.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション調整

sen.j: 古くは皇帝の長女を元公主（げんこうしゅ）と呼んだ（例：魯元公主（劉邦の長女））。
sen.e: In the ancient times, the eldest daughters of the emperors were titled Genkoshu (e.g., the eldest daughter of Liu Pang was called 魯元公主)

In ancient times, the eldest daughters of emperors were called as Genkoshu (e.g., the eldest daughter of Liu Pang was called "Lu (or Lo in Japanese) Genkoshu", 魯元公主, or the Genkoshu given the land in Lu).
sen.cmt: 表現の変更をしました。
sen.e: In ancient times, the eldest daughters of emperors were called as Genkoshu (e.g., the eldest daughter of Liu Pang was called "Lu (or Lo in Japanese) Genkoshu," 魯元公主, or the Genkoshu given the land in Lu).
sen.cmt: クォーテーション調整

sen.j: 唐宋以後、今上の姉妹は長公主（ちょうこうしゅ）、今上の伯叔母や数代前の公主は大長公主（だいちょうこうしゅ）（例：秦魯国賢穆明懿大長公主）と呼んで今上の娘と区別し、受けた待遇も公主より上だった。
sen.e: After the Tang and Song Dynasties, sisters of the reigning emperor were titled Chokoshu and aunts of the reigning emperor were titled Daichokoshu (e.g., 秦魯国賢穆明懿大長公主) to be distinguished from daughters of the reigning emperor.

From the Tang and Song Dynasties onwards, sisters of the reigning emperor were given the title of Chokoshu (roughly, elder Koshu), and aunts and Koshu ladies in the previous reigns were given the title of Daichokoshu (roughly, great elder koshu, e.g., 秦魯国賢穆明懿大長公主), to distinguish from daughters of the reigning emperor, with better treatment than the daughters.
sen.cmt: 唐宋時代の後かそれともその時代も入るのか微妙なので、Fron the …. Onwardsとしました。長公主、大長公主の長、大の意味が英語では落ちてしまうので適宜追加しました。数代前の公主、待遇も公主より上だった、が抜けていたので追加しました。
sen.e: From the Tang and Song Dynasties onwards, sisters of the reigning emperor were given the title of Chokoshu (roughly, elder Koshu), and aunts and Koshu ladies in the previous reigns were given the title of Daichokoshu (roughly, great elder koshu, e.g., 秦魯国賢穆明懿大長公主), to distinguish from daughters of the reigning emperor, with better treatment than the daughters.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 清代になって、公主にも階級が分けられ、生母が皇后か妃嬪かで固倫・和碩の別がついた。
sen.e: During the Qing Dynasty, Koshu was ranked so that daughters of the Empress were titled 固倫公主 and daughters of the concubine of the emperor were titled 和碩公主.
In the Qing Dynasty, the title of Koshu were distinguished into two: daughters of empresses were called as 固倫公主; and daughters of other imperial consorts as和碩公主.
sen.cmt: 妃の分類と地位は文化ごとに違っていて難しいので、concubine of the emperor ではなく imperial consorts で括りました。中国のさまざまな妃の英語表記でざっと使われていると思います。例：http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imperial_Consort_Zhen固倫、和碩の正しい読みがわからないので漢字のままにしました。
sen.e: In the Qing Dynasty, the title of Koshu were distinguished into two: daughters of empresses were called as 固倫公主; and daughters of other imperial consorts as和碩公主.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: また、北宋ではごく短い一時期、公主の称号を廃し、帝姫（ていき）の称号を用いていた（例：嘉徳帝姫）。
sen.e: In the Northern Sung dynasty, the title Koshu was abolished for a short time and the title Teiki (帝姫) was used instead (e.g., 嘉徳帝姫.)
In the Northern Sung dynasty, the title Koshu was abolished for a short time and the title Teiki (帝姫) was used instead (e.g., 嘉徳帝姫.)
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: In the Northern Sung dynasty, the title Koshu was abolished for a short time and the title Teiki (帝姫) was used instead (e.g., 嘉徳帝姫.)
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 周王朝風の呼び方だという。
sen.e: It is said that Teiki was the title in the style of Shou.
It is said that the title Teiki was in the style of the Shou dynasty.
sen.cmt: Shu --> the Shou dynasty
sen.e: It is said that the title Teiki was in the style of the Shou dynasty.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 臣下が公主を娶る（中国や朝鮮では原則的に同姓不婚であるため、当然ながら公主の結婚相手は臣下に限られる）ことを「尚公主」といい、その夫は駙馬都尉（清朝には額駙）と称呼した。
sen.e: The practice of the retainer of the emperor married Koshu was called '尚公主' and the retainer was titled 駙馬都尉 (during the Qing Dynasty,額駙) (As marriage between the man and woman with the same surname was tabooed in China and Korea, the husband of Koshu was unquestionably limited to the retainer of the emperor.)

When a subject of an emperor married a Koshu (any husband to a Koshu had to come from a different family, thus a non-sovereign family, as in China and Korea marriage within the family, thus with the same surname, has long been a taboo), it was called尚公主, and the husband was given a title of駙馬都尉 (during the Qing Dynasty, it was 額駙).
sen.cmt: 臣下が公主を娶る 習慣が「尚公主」ではなく、臣下が～娶った場合、と読んで調整しました。
sen.e: When a subject of an emperor married a Koshu (any husband to a Koshu had to come from a different family, thus a non-sovereign family, as in China and Korea marriage within the family, thus with the same surname, has long been a taboo), it was called尚公主, and the husband was given a title of駙馬都尉 (during the Qing Dynasty, it was 額駙).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 朝鮮では「コンジュ（）」と発音し、国王の正妃の生んだ娘を指していた（その他の後宮所生の娘は「翁主」）。
sen.e: In Korea, Koshu was pronounced as Konju, indicating the daughter by the legitimate queen of the emperor (the daughters gave birth by consorts of the emperors were titled '翁主' Oshu.)
In Korea, Koshu was pronounced as Konju, and indicated a daughter of a king and queen, while a daughter from other king consort was given a title of Okishu or 翁主.
sen.cmt: 朝鮮は基本は王なので、consorts of the emperorsは、kingsにしました。Queenというタイトルは他の理由がない限りlegitimateなのでこの語は外しました。
sen.e: In Korea, Koshu was pronounced as Konju, and indicated a daughter of a king and queen, while a daughter from other king consort was given a title of Okishu or 翁主.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 大韓帝国での公主は皇帝の皇后の生んだ娘を指していた。
sen.e: In Great Korean Empire, Koshu meant daughters gave birth by the empresses of the emperors.
Accordingly, the title Kosh was given to daughters of the emperor and empress in the Great Korean Empire (1887-1910).
sen.cmt: 上の文との関連で理解されるようaccordinglyを付けました。
sen.e: Accordingly, the title Kosh was given to daughters of the emperor and empress in the Great Korean Empire (1887-1910).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 現代中華人民共和国および大韓民国では、日本語の「お姫様」とほぼ同じ意味で用いられている。
sen.e: In the present People's Republic of China and the Republic of Korea, Koshu has almost the same meaning as 'O-himesama' in Japanese, meaning a princess.
In the present People's Republic of China and the Republic of Korea, Koshu has almost the same meaning as 'O-himesama' in Japanese, meaning a princess, without any legitimate claim to it.
sen.cmt: meaninga princess。Princessは正式なタイトルを意味する可能性のある語ですので、without any legitimate claim to itを付けました。
sen.e: In the present People's Republic of China and the Republic of Korea, Koshu has almost the same meaning as 'O-himesama' in Japanese, meaning a princess, without any legitimate claim to it.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 「公主」の称号の由来は、本来、天子の女の婚儀を三公が主宰した事による。
sen.e: The title 'Koshu' originated from the fact that three Ministers which were called 'three Ko' presided the marriages of the daughters of the monarchs.
The origin of this word 'Koshu' is explained by the fact that marriages of daughters of the monarch were presided (公) by three Ministers (each called as 公 or 侯).
sen.cmt: 日本語文でもこの由来の意味がわからなかったのですが、手持ちのブリタニカに、『中国で天子の娘をいう。諸侯（公）に結婚を主(つかさど）らせたのでこの名が出たといわれる。』とありまして、これなら分からなくはないので、原文の意味をそこなわないようにしつつ、意味を補いました。
sen.e: The origin of this word 'Koshu' is explained by the fact that marriages of daughters of the monarch were presided (公) by three Ministers (each called as 公 or 侯).
sen.cmt: 修正なし
